articles.headline: U.S. Presses the Airlines to Satisfy the Traveler
articles.snippet: Passengers would receive as much as $1,300 for being bumped and would have 24 hours to cancel reservations without penalty under the proposal.
articles.abstract: Passengers would receive as much as $1,300 for being bumped and would have 24 hours to cancel reservations without penalty under the proposal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department signaled on Wednesday that it planned to be more aggressive in forcing airlines to address common traveler frustrations, proposing a wide range of consumer protections. They come on top of earlier rules limiting how much time passengers can sit on planes on the tarmac.

articles.headline: Ford to End Production of Its Mercury Line
articles.snippet: Ford said it would stop producing Mercury vehicles and discontinue the brand.
articles.abstract: Ford said it would stop producing Mercury vehicles and discontinue the brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Edsel Ford conceived the Mercury brand in the 1930s as a way to fill the gap between basic Fords and luxury Lincolns. Now, that gap will again go unfilled.

articles.headline: As Certain as Taxes: New Version of Office
articles.snippet: Microsoft is about to release a new version of its best-selling software, spruced-up and ready to rumble with the likes of Google Docs.
articles.abstract: Microsoft is about to release a new version of its best-selling software, spruced-up and ready to rumble with the likes of Google Docs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Certain landmark events come around every few years, giving some reassuring structure to our lives. You know: Presidential elections. Summer Olympics. Remakes of “A Christmas Carol.”

articles.headline: Critics Question Study Cited in Health Debate
articles.snippet: A report is used to show that Americans could save while maintaining quality, but that may not always hold.
articles.abstract: A report is used to show that Americans could save while maintaining quality, but that may not always hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: In selling the health care overhaul to Congress, the Obama administration cited a once obscure research group at Dartmouth College to claim that it could not only cut billions in wasteful health care spending but make people healthier by doing so.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: At Toyota, a Cultural Shift
articles.snippet: Chastened by recalls, Toyota’s president is leading an effort to restore the automaker’s vital United States market.
articles.abstract: Chastened by recalls, Toyota’s president is leading an effort to restore the automaker’s vital United States market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, when Steve St. Angelo, a longtime executive at Toyota in the United States, traveled to Japan, it was an eye-opening journey.

articles.headline: Nuclear Option on Gulf Oil Spill? No Way, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Sealing the gulf oil well with a nuclear blast is among the wildest of ideas proposed sent to federal agencies and BP.
articles.abstract: Sealing the gulf oil well with a nuclear blast is among the wildest of ideas proposed sent to federal agencies and BP.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chatter began weeks ago as armchair engineers brainstormed for ways to stop the torrent of oil spilling into the Gulf of Mexico: What about nuking the well?

articles.headline: Heaviest Users of Phone Data Will Pay More
articles.snippet: AT&T will offer unlimited data plans to new smartphone customers, who will pay based on what they use.
articles.abstract: AT&T will offer unlimited data plans to new smartphone customers, who will pay based on what they use.
articles.lead_paragraph: They spend hours watching video on their phones, downloading songs, browsing the Web, sending photos to friends and generally using mobile devices as full-fledged computers. They are the data hogs.

articles.headline: New Israeli Tack Needed on Gaza, U.S. Officials Say
articles.snippet: The Obama administration considers Israel’s blockade of Gaza to be untenable and plans to press for another approach, U.S. officials said.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration considers Israel’s blockade of Gaza to be untenable and plans to press for another approach, U.S. officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration considers Israel’s blockade of Gaza to be untenable and plans to press for another approach to ensure Israel’s security while allowing more supplies into the impoverished Palestinian area, senior American officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: File-Sharing Pioneers Now Selling Music
articles.snippet: The founders of the file-sharing site Kazaa will unveil a venture, Rdio, which will allow users to stream and store music on a range of mobile phones.
articles.abstract: The founders of the file-sharing site Kazaa will unveil a venture, Rdio, which will allow users to stream and store music on a range of mobile phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the music business, they would call it a comeback.
